description.plain:
An indie-rock band based primarily Montreal, Quebec, Canada, Arcade Fire are fronted by husband and wife Win Butler and Régine Chassagne, as well as Richard Reed Parry, Tim Kingsbury, Will Butler (brother of Win), and Jeremy Gara. They usually tour with a large entourage of musicians, who occasionally outnumber “the band”. Their sound reflects that – tracks regularly feature all sections of the orchestra.

Arcade Fire was formed in 2001 in Montreal, Canada, by Win butler and Josh Deu, who were attending universities there. They were joined by Régine Chassagne and a rotating group of other musicians who helped round out the first incarnation of the band. Tensions rose in the band when they recorded their self-titled EP, Arcade Fire. Deu exited the band, and Perry, Kingsbury, Gara, and Will Butler joined the band, this being the final lineup.

Arcade Fire released their critically-acclaimed debut album Funeral in the fall of 2004. The album skyrocketed Arcade Fire into the mainstream, and Funeral was named one of the best albums of the year by many news sources.

Arcade Fire bought a run-down church in Quebec in 2006, converting it into a recording studio. They released their second album, Neon Bible, in 2007. The album went number one on many charts, reaching number 2 on the Billboard Hot 100. The album was, again, critically acclaimed. It featured an orchestral, dark sound, utilizing church instruments and classical instruments often more prominently than traditional rock instruments. The band donated thousands of dollars to charities, focusing on those in Chassagne’s home country of Haiti, and supported Barack Obama during his 2008 presidential campaign.

Arcade Fire’s third album, The Suburbs, was released in the summer of 2010. The album went back to a more traditional rock sound, with many sources comparing it to the work of Bruce Springsteen. Arcade Fire collaborated with Google to create an interactive video for their song We Used to Wait using Google Maps.

They also released the albums Reflektor in 2013, influenced by traditional Haitian music, and Everything Now in 2017.

Arcade Fire actively contributes to the awareness of Haitian people’s struggles and the country’s history, the latter being particularly emphasized in the track Haiti. In 2004, they played in two shows in its hometown and gave all profits to Albert Schweitzer’s hospital in Haiti. The song Rococo also relates to Haitian history.

songs.full_title: Abraham's Daughter by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Abraham’s Daughter

description.plain:
This song first appeared on the soundtrack to the 2012 film ‘The Hunger Games,’ starring Jennifer Lawrence. The film is based on the wildly-popular novel of the same name, the first in a trilogy of connected stories.

‘Abraham’s Daughter’ retell the Biblical story of Abraham’s near-sacrifice of his son Isaac, and includes an apocryphal character (Abraham’s unnamed daughter) witnessing and trying to intervene and stop the patriarch.

songs.full_title: Afterlife by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Afterlife

description.plain:
“Afterlife” had its debut on Saturday Night Live.

An official lyric video was released before the release of the Reflektor album, featuring clips from Orfeu Negro (Black Orpheus), a film made in Brazil by French director Marcel Camus.

This film is an adaptation of the myth of Orpheus, further linking the album to the myth.

songs.full_title: (Antichrist Television Blues) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: (Antichrist Television Blues)

description.plain:
This song had alternative titles as it was being created, including “Joe Simpson,” who is the father of Jessica Simpson and an inspiration for the narrator of the song (see https://www.stereogum.com/4615/win_butler_on_joe_simpson/news/)

The song, heavily based on Joe Simpson’s relationship with his daughter, tells a story of a man who considers himself a pious Christian, but begins using his daughter for fame and money, eventually sexually exploiting her, causing him to doubt his faith.

songs.full_title: Awful Sound (Oh Eurydice) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Awful Sound (Oh Eurydice)

description.plain: Awful Sound continues the story of two lovers set up by “Here Comes the Night Time II”. The album uses the fable of Orpheus and Eurydice as a metaphor for the toxic relationship of the couple, a man and a woman. Awful Sound narrated by the man as he attempts to understand his partner’s failing mental health.

songs.full_title: Black Mirror by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Black Mirror

description.plain:
Neon Bible is, in some ways, an unwelcome and very welcome departure from Arcade Fire’s predominately indie and cathartic songs from before. The first line, if you’ve heard this album enough, refers to one walking to the ocean, a grand and open area. Much like this album, the ocean is huge and has a much bigger scope than what was before, land, or their previous effort Funeral. Funeral, which Pitchfork described as “the band looking inward” in their Neon Bible review, is the complete opposite of what Neon Bible tries to accomplish. Neon Bible is indeed looking outward rather than inward: instead of pain, catharsis, and emotions, we have themes on seduction, television, mass media, ads, religion, oppression, Orwellian worlds, escape, and generally a “what has the world come to?” kind of feel to it.

Throughout Neon Bible, the ocean is also used as a symbol for lack of control (“Ocean of Noise”, “Black Wave”, to name a few), which is touched on in “Black Mirror” as well.

Now for the song, we have the concept of “black mirrors,” or, really, screens. Phones, TV’s, computers, you name it, which are given a negative connotation based on the fact that you can’t really express your true self on them. Like the song “Reflektor”, phones and devices are controlling us instead of us controlling them.

songs.full_title: Black Wave / Bad Vibrations by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Black Wave / Bad Vibrations

description.plain:
The title of the song is a reference to the Beach Boys' masterpiece, “Good Vibrations”.

This song is generally about trying to escape one’s past to form a new identity and create a new future.
 Although, sometimes it is difficult to escape the past, when there are so many things that you can get caught up in.

songs.full_title: Chemistry by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Chemistry

description.plain:
“Chemistry” is the sixth track on Arcade Fire’s Everything Now.

The song follows a man who has fallen in love with this girl, but she doesn’t feel the same.  While this man does everything in his power to convince her that they have “Chemistry” together.

This song has a very nostalgic feel to it, with back up singers used to repeat everything that Win says in the Pre-Chorus', while also integrating a very disco melody.

songs.full_title: City with No Children by Arcade Fire
songs.title: City with No Children

description.plain:
The 6th track off Arcade Fire’s Grammy winning masterpiece The Suburbs draws on the album’s introspective themes of youth and adulthood, whilst drawing on biblical imagery. The lead songwriter Win Butler and his brother Will were brought up as Mormons, and this influence is clearly seen in this song.

“City with No Children” is used as a metaphor for a city with its life sucked out of it. Butler muses on images of childhood, and details their destruction, through war, a failing engine, or simply forgetting who we once were. Therein lies the tragedy of the transition from childhood to adulthood explored on the album – a complete transformation of character where the child within us dies, and we learn to accept the harsh realities of life.

songs.full_title: Creature Comfort by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Creature Comfort

description.plain:
Creature Comfort (an object that makes a person feel more comfortable or happy) was first played at Arcade Fire`s surprise warmup gig at Primavera Festival, on 01/06/2017
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZIX235C6mxU

Later, on 16/06/2017, the single was officially released across all streaming apps.

The song seems to be about depression, suicidal thoughts, and suicide itself, the latter of which is symbolized by the phrase “creature comfort”.

songs.full_title: Crown of Love by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Crown of Love

description.plain: Even in its darkest moments, Funeral exudes an empowering positivity. Slow-burning ballad “Crown of Love” is an expression of lovesick guilt that perpetually crescendos until the track unexpectedly explodes into a dance section, still soaked in the melodrama of weeping strings; the song’s psychological despair gives way to a purely physical catharsis.

songs.full_title: Crucified Again by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Crucified Again

description.plain:
This song features on 2015’s deluxe version of Reflektor, but the group had been playing it live at least twice before its official release. Whilst it bears some lyrical resemblance to “Here Comes The Night Time” – specifically the references to televangelists criticising Haiti – they are separate songs, and “Crucified Again” featured in Arcade Fire’s live sets in Haiti during the Reflektor tour.

The subject of the song is the 2010 Haiti earthquake. There are lots of uses Neon Bible-style of religious imagery.

The two existing live recordings of the song are quite different. The first features Win Butler on organ and Sarah Neufeld’s violin prominently. The second recording is based primarily around Win Butler’s acoustic guitar and vocals.

The two existing live recordings of the song are quite different. The first features Win Butler on organ and Sarah Neufeld’s violin prominently. The second recording is based primarily around Win Butler’s acoustic guitar and vocals.

songs.full_title: Culture War by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Culture War

description.plain:
This song addresses the “culture war” that is occurring between traditionalists and the modern world. Seemingly angered by their pontificating, Butler indicts the conservatives for preaching about a war that doesn’t need to exist. This song is a plea for tolerance.

The future remains an ominous and bleak forbear that, although Butler lambastes conservatives, he is also fearful of what remains to come.

songs.full_title: Everything Now by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Everything Now

description.plain:
The first single from Arcade Fire’s fifth studio album, Everything Now, was released while the band played a secret set at Primavera Sound in Barcelona. A clip had already been released from a record shop in Barcelona, as a vinyl had gone on sale at Primevera Sound Festival before the official release of the song.

The song shares themes of technological alienation and contemporary impatience with songs like “We Used To Wait”, “Reflektor”, and “Neon Bible”, but is relatively optimistic. Although Win Butler’s narrator harshly satirizes modern on-demand culture and consumerism in general, Regine Chassagne’s piano and some passionate backing vocals turn the song into one of Arcade Fire’s sunniest anthems, as the chorus is plea to their fans to “Wake Up”, take control, and give everything they have to try to make the world and society we live in a better place for all of us. Interpreting the chorus with this double entendre, “I can’t live without it” may mean that they would rather die than live in a world ruled by callousness and greed.

songs.full_title: Everything_Now (continued) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Everything_Now (continued)

description.plain:
“Everything_Now (continued)” is the first track in Arcade Fire’s Everything Now.

This song begins with the ending of the album’s final track “Everything Now (continued)” – creating an ‘infinity loop’ where the album can be played start-to-finish over and over, seemingly without ending.

This song is also used as an segue to track two, “Everything Now”, and was originally debut in the song’s music video as an Intro.

songs.full_title: Good God Damn by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Good God Damn

description.plain:
“Good God Damn” is the tenth track on Arcade Fire’s Everything Now.  Fans have noticed that this song is from the point of view of the girl whose story is featured on “Creature Comfort”

Told me she came so close
Filled up the bathtub and put on our first record

The song depicts a person with suicidal thoughts preparing their death, but beginning to reconsider as they consider faith or a higher power, the titular ‘Good God’, ultimately resulting in them backing out.

songs.full_title: Half Light I by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Half Light I

description.plain: “Half Light I” forms the centerpiece of The Suburbs along with “Half Light II” This track explores the idea of growing up and seeing the Suburbs in a different light, a recurring theme on the album. This track is a slower paced ballad accompanied by soft vocals and gorgeous strings that help bring to life the imagery of running through suburbia at night.

songs.full_title: Headlights Look Like Diamonds by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Headlights Look Like Diamonds

description.plain:
“Headlights Look Like Diamonds” was written by Win Butler and Régine Chassagne, the married couple at the heart of Arcade Fire, on their first date as a couple (although she disputes the fact it was a date).

It’s been a fan favourite ever since, and after going through a period of absence from their live sets while touring in support of The Suburbs, has recently returned as a live track.

songs.full_title: I Dreamed a Neil Young Song by Arcade Fire (Ft. Neil Young)
songs.title: I Dreamed a Neil Young Song
songs.title_with_featured: I Dreamed a Neil Young Song (Ft. Neil Young)

description.plain:
This song was inspired by a nightmare Win had. As he was soundchecking a new Arcade Fire song, the crowd all got up and left.

He woke up and frantically scribbled down the lyrics and tune, like Keith Richards did with “(I Can’t Get No) Satisfaction”. The song reminded him of a Neil Young song, so he named it “I Dreamed A Neil Young Song”.

The song debuted on October 26, 2013 at the 27th annual Bridge School Benefit concert, organized by Young and his wife Pegi, and Neil came onstage to join the band for this song.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WB597D24XB0

songs.full_title: I Give You Power by Arcade Fire (Ft. Mavis Staples)
songs.title: I Give You Power
songs.title_with_featured: I Give You Power (Ft. Mavis Staples)

description.plain:
Officially released the day before the inauguration of President Trump, “I Give You Power” was originally announced as a charity single rather than the first promotional single for Arcade Fire’s fifth studio album. Live versions had been floating around the internet since May 2016.

In the studio version, Win Butler provides call-and-response vocals with R&B alto Mavis Staples over a dance beat that takes the sound of Reflektor to the extreme. The hook is reminiscent of “Gold Digger” by Kanye West, but the huge organ roots the song to Neon Bible.

songs.full_title: Infinite Content by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Infinite Content

description.plain:
Continuing the themes of consumerism in the modern age, with Win’s anecdotes just as relevant to this track as they were for the title track “Everything Now”, “Infinite Content” and its counterpart “Infinite_Content” serve as an almost comedic payoff to the marketing campaign and endless sea of sponsorship deals (both real and fake). There’s no such thing as a free lunch, so you’ve already spent your money on listening to this, be it through heavily encouraged pre-orders, standard purchases, streams or downloads.

These two songs may mark the middle of the album, but cyclical nature of the album only furthers this “infinite content” concept, although it can be seen on the whole as a comment on the amount of media society consumes on the whole and the rate at which we do.

https://twitter.com/arcadefire/status/886994727933030402

songs.full_title: In the Backseat by Arcade Fire
songs.title: In the Backseat

description.plain: This song describes the singer’s sudden thrusting into control of her own life after the death of her mother Alice. She describes her life before her mother’s death as “being in the back seat” or being able to let go of the wheel and move through life while “watching the countryside.” With her mother’s death, the singer is sudden “crashing towards the driver’s seat” and is now tasked with establishing control over the movement of her life. She has been learning to drive her whole life, now it is finally time to take the wheel and she can no longer find the peace of being in the backseat.

songs.full_title: It's Never Over (Hey Orpheus) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: It’s Never Over (Hey Orpheus)

description.plain:
There are two ways to interpret “It’s Never Over (Hey Orpheus).” First, it’s clearly a literal retelling of the Greek myth of Orpheus and Eurydice, in which Orpheus was permitted to bring his beloved Eurydice back from Hades so long as he did not look at her until they crossed the River Styx. In this telling, they must wait until the journey is over.

Even if the song is literal as a standalone work, its inclusion on the album Reflektor is fraught with meaning. Reflektor is a unified meditation on Soren Kierkegaard’s concept of passionate versus reflective ages. In Win Butler’s own words: “If there was a piece of gold out on thin ice, in a passionate age, if someone went to try and get the gold, everyone would cheer them on and be like, ‘Go for it! Yeah you can do it!’ And in a reflective age, if someone tried to walk out on the thin ice, everyone would criticize them and say, ‘What an idiot! I can’t believe you’re going out on the ice to try and risk something.’” Butler believes we live in a reflective age, which motivated him to (1) “want[] to try and make something in the world instead of just talking about things,” namely by branching out musically from his rock comfort zone with new dance, electronic, trance, and rara elements, and (2) tell stories of passionate acts in passionate ages, such as Orpheus’s ill-fated rescue of Eurydice.

The second principal way to view the song is representative, not merely literal. Here, the options for a deep hidden meaning (“DHM,” in the parlance of the Butlers' alma mater) splinter. It could be a love song: We’ll get through this together. This is the most obvious interpretation. But Arcade Fire seldom produces straight love songs. It could be an echo of Suburbs-era angst about “moving past the feeling”: Let’s survive these suburbs until we can make it to liberal utopia. This interpretation is indicated by the bridge discussion of something seeming like a big deal now, age, and nostalgia. But Arcade Fire seldom dwells on a lyrical theme for longer than an album.

The real mind-blower may be to consider that the song is simultaneously (1) a literal recounting of a Greek myth, (2) the story of a passionate act to inspire “the kids” in our reflective age, and (3) an allegorical representation in which Orpheus (Arcade Fire) attempts to rescue Eurydice (the listener) by embodying passion until it (our reflective age) is over. Now that’s a reflektor!

songs.full_title: Joan of Arc by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Joan of Arc

description.plain: This song exists on two levels. First, it tells the tale of Joan of Arc, the Frenchwoman who, according to a vision she claims to have seen when she was twelve, helps inspire the French drive out the English army and reclaim France for the French. It also addresses Arcade Fire’s status as a behemoth in the world of alternative rock, leading to the comparison by some fans to a Joan of Arc-esque figure. The band rejects such an identity, not believing themselves to be the “savior” of this form of music, however they draw comparisons between the relationship of fans and a band to the followers of Joan of Arc. At the very end, the band leaves a rather ambiguous statement, proclaiming that “First they love you, then they kill you, then they love you again.” This shows the treatment that fans often give their object of idolation

songs.full_title: Keep the Car Running by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Keep the Car Running

description.plain:
The 2nd track off Neon Bible is generally about not giving up, or, keeping the car running. Butler himself has noted the Orwellian references throughout. The song paints a picture in a dystopian land where commercialism and oppression rule, and the protagonist’s escape from it.

It’s hard not to be cynical about certain things. I just finished reading this George Orwell book, Why I Write, and he’s talking about England during World War II, the political culture. There are some criticisms he had of the left that hit me pretty hard. Not that I really consider myself left or right or whatever, but he was criticizing people who put down bravery. It really made a lot of sense to me. There’s this negative approach to the world, and I definitely find myself falling into that at times. He was just saying that patriotism and intelligence need to coexist, or else the world really goes to shit. I thought that was a powerful idea. Actual patriotism has to do with loving a place enough to try and improve it.
-Win Butler on A.V. Club

songs.full_title: Month of May by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Month of May

description.plain:
By the time The Suburbs came out in 2010, Arcade Fire had already successfully transitioned from indie darlings to hanging with Bruce Springsteen, and their sound started to transition too. While Funeral and Neon Bible sounded like albums to be played in churches, The Suburbs sounds more fit for a stadium.

“Month of May” is the perfect example—a driving rock song with a touch of panic. It remains the most aggressive rock song Arcade Fire has ever written, and it’s one of many risks the band has taken that paid off.

One reason Arcade Fire has managed to stay interesting after all these years is because they’ve never been afraid to expand their palette. Sometimes that means experimentation and challenging the listener—other times, it just means making a straightforward rock song.

songs.full_title: My Body Is a Cage by Arcade Fire
songs.title: My Body Is a Cage

description.plain:
“My Body Is a Cage” is the contemplative final track of Arcade Fire’s 2007 sophomore album, Neon Bible. The drum beat in the background beats like a heart’s pulse, and the baroque-like backing pipes create an intense listening experience.

Lead singer Win Butler’s weary voice leads the song like a light in the mist, letting you take a dive into Butler’s personal issues. In the words of NPR,

One part soulful ballad and one part philosophical dilemma: If he and only he is responsible for his freedom, then why the hesitation? Why not go barreling straight into freedom?

The song gained popularity recently after being featured in an episode of HBO’s Euphoria, and was also featured in a TV spot for the 2008 film, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button.

songs.full_title: My Buddy by Arcade Fire (Ft. Alvino Rey Orchestra)
songs.title: My Buddy

description.plain:
This song is not a cover, but an actual recording by Alvino Rey and his wife Luise from 1940. It was used as a b-side of the Neighborhood #2 (Laika) single in tribute to Rey, who was Win and Will Butler’s maternal grandfather, and whose death was one of those that inspired the title and tone of the band’s debut. Rey was a pioneer of early electric instruments, and addition to the first pickups for electric guitar and banjo, he invented an early version of Peter Frampton’s talkbox called the Sonovox, which is responsible for the seemingly anachronistic effect present on this recording.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYuUnJxcMzU

songs.full_title: Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels)

description.plain: “Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels)” is a sumptuously theatrical opener– the gentle hum of an organ, undulating strings, and repetition of a simple piano figure suggest the discreet unveiling of an epic. Butler, in a bold voice that wavers with the force of raw, unspoken emotion, introduces his neighborhood. The scene is tragic: As a young man’s parents weep in the next room, he secretly escapes to meet his girlfriend in the town square, where they naively plan an “adult” future that, in the haze of adolescence, is barely comprehensible to them. Their only respite from their shared uncertainty and remoteness exists in the memories of friends and parents.

songs.full_title: Neighborhood #2 (Laïka) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Neighborhood #2 (Laïka)

description.plain: The conventionally rock-oriented “Neighborhood #2 (Laïka)” is a second-hand account of one individual’s struggle to overcome an introverted sense of suicidal desperation. The lyrics superficially suggest a theme of middle-class alienation, but avoid literal allusion to a suburban wasteland– one defining characteristic of the album, in fact, is the all-encompassing scope of its conceptual neighborhoods.

songs.full_title: Neighborhood #3 (Power Out) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Neighborhood #3 (Power Out)

description.plain:
Neighborhood #3 (Power Out) is a shimmering, audacious anthem that combines a driving pop beat, ominous guitar assault, and sprightly glockenspiel decoration into a passionate, fist-pumping album manifesto. The fluidity of the song’s construction is mesmerizing, and the cohesion of Butler’s poignant assertion of exasperation (I went out into the night/ I went out to pick a fight with anyone) and his emotional call to arms (“The power’s out in the heart of man/ Take it from your heart/ Put it in your hand), distinguishes the song as the album’s towering centerpiece.

Arcade Fire named the album this song is on Funeral partly due to the fact that they lost a number of friends while recording. But those losses sparked a more general contemplation of the contribution of the older generations and how they both affected and were affected by the passage of time in the twentieth century.

In this light, “Neighborhood #3 (Power Out)” is set in the North American economic boom of the ‘80s and ‘90s. It has been suggested that there was a blizzard in '98 that may have inspired this song, and it’s an interesting coincidence that the end of the '90s was also the culmination of years of economic prosperity and the beginning of a downward turn in the stock market and, more broadly, in the fortunes of the Western world.

songs.full_title: Neighborhood #4 (7 Kettles) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Neighborhood #4 (7 Kettles)

description.plain:
Perhaps the most understated of all of the “Neighboorhood” tracks from Funeral, “7 Kettles” is Butler’s reflection on the inevitable passage of time. The ‘watched pot’ in the refrain is time itself. Butler says that people feel that they can stop time if they ‘watch’ it or focus on a particular moment, but regardless of whether his eyes are closed or not, the passage of time is inevitable. On “Kettles” he switched from cliché to oddity in a single line and the effect is oddly moving.

They say a watched pot never boils/ you can’t raise a baby on motor oil."

songs.full_title: No Cars Go by Arcade Fire
songs.title: No Cars Go

description.plain:
One of the most popular songs on Neon Bible, “No Cars Go” is an epic anthem that builds to a joyous climax, but is still one of the most immediate songs in Arcade Fire’s discography. It tells of late-night escapism from a world dominated by cars and planes.

It was originally recorded for their self-released debut EP, but was spruced up for the release of Neon Bible.

description.plain:
No Cars Go is the third song on Arcade Fire’s EP titled “Arcade Fire.” Arcade Fire’s This song’s title is taken from former Arcade Fire member Brendan Reed’s solo act, Nocarsgo.

No Cars Go has been featured in many videos and promotionals, including the short documentary film “Love the Beast” by Eric Bana. It was also featured in the preview of Top Gear Season 10.

The song is listed on some vinyl pressings as the B-side “Surf City Eastern Block” or sometimes “Surf City Eastern Bloc.”

No Cars Go was re-recorded for Neon Bible.

songs.full_title: Normal Person by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Normal Person

description.plain:
Alienation is one of the central themes of Reflektor, and nowhere is it more explicit than on “Normal Person”. It simultaneously captures the spirit of universal “us-vs-them” teenage counterculture, and deconstructs it by rubbishing the very notion of a Normal Person.

Musically, Butler’s half-whispered vocal evokes David Bowie and Iggy Pop in a smoke-filled studio in West Berlin. But the song evolves into a garage-rock headbanger, thanks largely to a solo guitar that could have come from a White Stripes session.

songs.full_title: Ocean of Noise by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Ocean of Noise

description.plain:
The 5th track off Neon Bible explores the concept of an “ocean of noise” we live in. Similarly referenced in their track Reflektor, that time called the “Reflektive Age”, the “ocean” is a symbol in many songs in Neon Bible for lack of control. The “noise” is the sound heard by a person just entering the real world of consumerism, propaganda, etc.

Virtually no control over anything is possible in the real world. Your parents help you much less, violence always lurks, and the “streets are empty” (no cars, or, no control).

songs.full_title: Peter Pan by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Peter Pan

description.plain:
“Peter Pan” is the fifth song on Arcade Fire’s new album Everything Now.  The song gathers inspiration from the fictional character Peter Pan, created by J.M. Barrie. He has the ability to fly and never grow up. He lives on an island called Neverland.

Barrie’s popular novel Peter Pan and Wendy was later turned into a Disney movie in 1953.

Wendy is a young girl who is hinted to have romantic feelings for him. In the books, Peter does not share her feelings, while in other works based on Barrie’s books the feelings are mutual.



In an interview with Zane Lowe for Apple Music, Win said:

I wrote ‘Peter Pan’ basically [when] I found out my dad was sick. I woke up in the middle of the night and wrote that song – every lyric in it.

He acknowledges that the lyrics came from an understanding that comes when you approach a certain age where people, including yourself, start losing parents.

https://youtu.be/0xOwifZ_BN4?t=37m24s

Our narrator insists he isn’t like the “little boys” whose relationships with women have been warped by porn, but still acknowledges that he hurt his girlfriend by withholding something from her.

songs.full_title: Put Your Money on Me by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Put Your Money on Me

description.plain: “Put Your Money on Me” details an intense love, and dives into the various uses and effects of money and how it changes people. It is viewed as a sign of confidence or strength in an uncertain scenario, but also as a necessary evil and corrupting force. Money is used as a metaphor to show Win’s willingness to save this relationship, even if it’s destroying him or changing him forever.

songs.full_title: Ready to Start by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Ready to Start

description.plain:
This song is capable of being incredibly inspiring to average, everyday listeners just as much as it is to Arcade Fire.

Anyone who has ever worked for “the man” knows how unfulfilling it can be to spend your days satisfying the agendas of your employer. That’s why this song could also be considered a rally cry for those who no longer want to be owned by those they are paid to bow down to. It encourages you to “open your mind”, “step out into the dark”, and be “ready to start” living out the passions of your own life.

songs.full_title: Rebellion by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Rebellion

description.plain:
This was the forth single from Arcade Fire’s ridiculously well received 2004 album Funeral. Both the song and the album appeared near the top of many Best of the Decade lists.

The album is concerned with the concept of childhood – this song covers one of the most exciting phases, when children begin rebelling. They are fighting their parents lies and struggling to work out what’s real and what’s not. Much of this rebellion takes place in bed, either while dreaming or with lovers.

songs.full_title: Rebellion (Lies) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Rebellion (Lies)

description.plain:
The penultimate song on Funeral remains one of Arcade Fire’s best-loved anthems. As on many of the album’s songs, Win Butler adopts the persona of a defiant child, rebelling against the lie that sleep is more important than water.

Arcade Fire performing “Rebellion (Lies)” at the Domaine National de Saint-Cloud in Paris, France for the 2007 Rock en Seine Festival:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v7GjucHCQ5Y

songs.full_title: Rococo by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Rococo

description.plain:
A look at conformism in today’s youth.

The major theme is that these young people go around using words such as “Rococo” to sound educated and artsy, without really knowing what it means.

Rococo is a style of art that was popular in France during the 18th century. It is sometimes criticized for being an era where French citizens were rich enough to spend large amounts on art without actually having much taste or culture.

As an extension, this Rococo era can be compared to the modern day, where people are encouraged to consume art for outward appearances, rather than appreciating it for their own pleasure.

songs.full_title: Signs of Life by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Signs of Life

description.plain:
While announcing “Signs of Life” in a June 30, 2017 Facebook post Arcade fire wrote:

The song is either about the futility of seeking meaning in a meaningless world or a celebration of a bangin' night in the club; the band would not confirm or deny either interpretation. It prominently features handclaps.

The song treads a careful midpoint between these two interpretations, presenting individuals who go out, party, and have meaningless sex, hoping to find meaning and connection with others. Their search is ultimately fruitless.

songs.full_title: Sprawl I (Flatland) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Sprawl I (Flatland)

description.plain:
Sprawl is another word to describe the suburbs. Usually used in the combinations “urban sprawl” or “suburban sprawl”. As Wikipedia describes it:

… describes the expansion of human populations away from central urban areas into low-density, monofunctional and usually car-dependent communities.

This is pretty much the theme of the two Sprawl songs, and indeed most of the album.

songs.full_title: Suburban War by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Suburban War

description.plain:
This song is mainly about Win Butler’s old friend, and this song is the main theme of their short film, Scenes From The Suburbs.

In this film, the main character’s best friend, Winter, becomes strangely distant from the rest of the group, and is believed to be the person talked about in this song.

So in short, this song is probably about and old friend of Win (or somebody else in Arcade Fire), how their friendship has changed, and how things such as different preferences in music can change lives. The power of music.

songs.full_title: The Suburbs by Arcade Fire
songs.title: The Suburbs

description.plain:
The first song on Arcade Fire’s 2010 album The Suburbs. Like their other work, it’s concerned with growing up, but isn’t fictional – it’s about band members Win and Will Butler’s childhood in suburban Texas. They described it as:

Neither a love letter to, nor an indictment of, the suburbs – it’s a letter from the suburbs."

It exposes some of the darkness and hidden fears in a seemingly idyllic childhood and introduces some of the albums' themes including war, youth, and loss of innocence.

songs.full_title: The Suburbs (Continued) by Arcade Fire
songs.title: The Suburbs (Continued)

description.plain: The final song on the album, “The Suburbs (Continued)” is a short but poignant testament to the themes of childhood, memory, and growth that run throughout. The Suburbs often looks back on the past rather ambivalently, but here Win and Régine dismiss this notion and come to realize, that as much as they might sometimes dismiss the time spent wasted in the past, if given the chance they would only have as much mindless fun as they did in the beginning.

songs.full_title: Wake Up by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Wake Up

description.plain:
Here we are, then: the gleaming jewel in Arcade Fire’s crown. Few bands in 2005 have proved quite so emotionally affecting as this Montreal-based orchestral rock septet, perhaps because no band has sounded quite so emotionally affected. You see, Arcade Fire deal with The Big Questions. Life. Death. Funeral arrangements. Violin tunings. And on ‘Wake Up’, they channel these questions into a rock symphony – yes, we said ‘symphony’ – that’s simultaneously sonically adventurous, emotionally harrowing and filled with real humanity.

Now, sure, LOTS OF BANDS have sounded this emotionally affected. Keep in mind, by 2005 we were at peak Emo. Sunny Day Real Estate and emotional hardcore was long forgotten. Bright Eyes were past their prime and kind of a joke. Sun Kil Moon was fizzling out into indie obscurity. Wilco had just released A Ghost is Born.  But what makes this song and Arcade Fire fresh is how they channel that energy into a positive and constructive direction without sounding trite or corny. And that is what gives this song its staying power.

This song, in fact, is so powerful that attracted the attention of quite a few famous musicians shortly after its release – U2 played “Wake Up” over the stadium loudspeakers to open concerts during their 2005 Vertigo tour and David Bowie covered it with Arcade Fire at Fashion Rocks the same year.

songs.full_title: We Don't Deserve Love by Arcade Fire
songs.title: We Don’t Deserve Love

description.plain:
“The Suburbs” provided a time capsule for a generation that could remember a time before The Internet. This song (and album) cap off a thesis for a generation that can remember a time before “Everything Now”. There is so much news, so much useless information that flashes in front of us every single moment, that we are now all part of the din, building a cage around ourselves and walls between the people we know. As we walk in the dark, we have lost the big picture, sacrificing our humanity and love for each other as we seek to fill every moment with more things to consume, consume, consume. “We Don’t Deserve Love” is a song for people that look up, only to find they’ve been left behind.

Using the Biblical story about how Mary returned to the tomb of Jesus, only to find that he had already resurrected and moved on; Win Butler goes on a path wondering whether there could be a God that can still love us all despite all our sins. However, that is not the central question he ends with in the end.

More importantly, he wants to know Why we don’t deserve love. If there is a God, he wants him to come off his cross and answer him.

Arcade Fire albums are now 5-for-5 in terms of life-affirming penultimate tracks. They always know to include a thank you note for the effort you put in listening to their albums. They know you feel ridiculous for caring so much when it’s way cooler to do the opposite.

songs.full_title: We Exist by Arcade Fire
songs.title: We Exist

description.plain:
The second track on Reflektor deals with a young man coming to terms with his homosexuality.

There’s a song on Reflektor called “We Exist”, which is about a gay kid talking to his dad (“Daddy, it’s true, I’m different from you. But tell me why they treat me like this?”). In dominant cultures there’s what’s normal, and everything else is abnormal. It’s one of the darker tendencies of humanity to think everyone should fit into a mould.
-Win Butler, Time Out Magazine



The music video tells the story of a pre-op transwoman. Finally summoning the courage to visit a bar, she is attacked. The realism of the video then disappears; there is a very camp dance sequence, and she is shown performing with the band (footage taken from their Coachella performance in 2014).

songs.full_title: Windowsill by Arcade Fire
songs.title: Windowsill

description.plain: This song is all about watching everything lose control. Win said for that the medium motives for the album were TV and the ocean. He said the ocean represents lack of control. About TV he said that commercials and basically the point of view on the life from TV is affecting everyone including him. Therefore he can’t handle to see that loss of control in his sight (the tide rising still).

songs.lyrics:
You tried to turn away my fears
Shouting metaphysics in my fifteen year old ears
I dreamed all day of sneaking out the window
A sigh for every other breath
When you are joyful I feel better
You catch a cold that lasts forever
A quest and we are hiding in the shadows
Beneath blue blazers and the smell of old books
Your eyes are blue, your voice is deep
In half a verse you sung my whole, whole world to sleep
And in a classroom underground
I am still aching for that old still sound
Then we know that patience is the most important part
What's the point of being patient for a broken heart?
I wish I was as passive as a patient on a table
It seems to me that you will die as soon as you are ableEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
